title: Show HN: Ping Rfc6921.net (April Fools')
text:
A server that replies to your pings faster than ever! Give it a minute and the response time will go down tremendously.

Works best on MacOS and FreeBSD.

On Windows the result is boring and you need to add an option not to stop after 4 pings:

  ping -t rfc6921.net

ChatGPT 4 > ChatGPT plugins (Alpha) – Wolfram on historical astronomy?
text:
Query: "When did Halley's Comet appear in the 15th and 16th centuries?"

ChatGPT plugins: (after four failing attempts using Wolfram) "I apologize for the inconvenience. It seems that I'm unable to retrieve the specific appearances of Halley's Comet in the 15th and 16th centuries using the available data. However, I can provide some general information about Halley's Comet. . . "

ChatGPT 4: "Halley's Comet, which has an orbital period of about 75-76 years, made two appearances in the 15th and 16th centuries:

In the 15th century, it appeared in 1456. This appearance was particularly noteworthy because it was observed and documented by astronomers, and its connection to previous sightings in 1378 and 1301 was recognized. This helped to establish the periodic nature of Halley's Comet. In the 16th century, it appeared in 1531. This appearance was also well-documented, and it further solidified the idea that Halley's Comet was a periodic comet that returned to the inner solar system on a regular schedule."

It is interesting that ChatGPT plugins apparently painted itself into a local minimum, through resort to Wolfram, rather than use its general ability gleaned from training.

Ask HN: Aggregate chunk embeddings to create intermediate-level representations
text:
TL;DR What are the current best practices for semantic search over a set of chunked documents? And, in particular, what is the most economic approach today (best "bang for the buck," if you will), taking into account the commercial or open-source tools that are currently available? Or... am I thinking about this all wrong and there's a better way to do it?

Details:

I have a set of documents against which I would like to run a semantic search. I'm thinking of using langchain to chunk the documents, generate embeddings for each chunk, and then go from there.

The difficulty, of course, is that concepts in the documents may span chunks, including non-contiguous chunks, and so we need more than just the chunk embeddings for this search to work.

From research, I'm aware of the following methods for aggregating the chunk embeddings to create a document-level representation: average pooling, max-pooling and weighted average. I'm aware that there are advantages and drawbacks to each of these approaches.

I'm also aware, from a quick scan of the literature, of techniques such as Vector of Locally-Aggregated Word Embeddings (VLAWE)[1].

I'm also open to building a solution, so it's fine if the answer is "Look at what they do in [some paper], it shouldn't be too hard to implement that."

[1]: https://aclanthology.org/N19-1033/
